results.title: Donnie Brasco (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Mike Newell, Barry Levinson, Gail Mutrux, Louis Digiamo, Mark Johnson and Mandalay Entertainment
results.brief_description: This is a gangster movie quite like no other which is more concerned with character study, friendship and betrayal. Donnie Brasco (Johnny Depp), also known as Joe the Jeweller, befriends Mafia small man and former assassin Lefty Ruggiero (Al Pacino). Lefty sees in the young Donnie a chance to rise in the Mafia ranks, something the aging Lefty, with his drug addicted son and passive wife is no longer capable of. Unbeknown to Lefty, Donnie Brasco is an under cover special agent, working with the FBI to infiltrate the New York Mafia underworld. What at first seems a simple case of undercover work is complicated by Donnie’s genuine feelings of friendship towards Lefty and Lefty’s loyalty towards Donnie. Based on the book by Joseph D. Pistone with Richard Woodley. Also starring Michael Madsen, Bruno Kirby, James Russo and Anne Heche.

results.title: While the city sleeps
results.creator_credit: Fritz Lang, Burt Friedlob and RKO Radio Pictures
results.brief_description: The editorship of a major city newspaper comes to rest upon the search for a psychopathic murderer (the “lipstick killer”). Although widely dismissed or neglected by critics, this is a film which Lang regarded as equal to his classic ‘M’. Thematically it bears comparison in the implication that socially acceptable levels of society are little different from the noir underworld. The murderer is more sympathetic than the newspaper people. There are also explicit parallels between the murderer and the ‘hero’ played by Dana Andrews, who at one stage uses his girlfriend as ‘bait’ for the killer. Stylistically this is Lang at his most lucidly refined. Cast includes Dana Andrews, George Sanders, Rhonda Fleming, George Sanders, Vincent Price and Ida Lupino. Based on the novel “The Bloody Spur” by Charles Einstein.

results.title: Pandora's box = Die Buchse der Pandora = Lulu
results.brief_description: A chronicle of the last months of Lulu’s life has been extracted from Wedekind’s play with more emphasis on thematic and psychological continuity than dramatic unity. Pabst portrays a gallery of characters ranging from the masochistic Schon to the compulsively psychotic Jack the Ripper - and Countess Geschwitz, the screen’s first unequivocal lesbian - with psychological acuity. Lulu, guileless and sexually ambiguous, is to Tony Rayns “the literal calm eye of the storm”. Further, Brooks’s performance is “passive” yet vital, suspended with candour and precision between innocence and childishly fleeting - but intense - emotions. Her emotional vitality and Pabst’s unobtrusive cutting on action make Pandora the most “modern” of silent classics. Cast includes Louise Brooks, Fritz Kortner, Franz Lederer, Carl Goetz, Carl Raschig and Alice Roberts. Adapted from Wedekind’s plays “Erdgeist” and “Die Buchse der Pandora”. Review by Tony Rayns, Monthly Film Bulletin, May 1974.

results.title: Father of the bride
results.creator_credit: Vincente Minnelli, Pandro S. Berman and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
results.brief_description: Stanley Banks is a secure middle-class lawyer whose daughter, Kay, announces her wedding plans to Bickley Dunstan. From that point on, everything in Stanley’s life is turned upside down. His wife, Ellie, wants Kay to have the kind of formal wedding that she and Stanley never had. In between meeting his soon-to-be in-laws, his man-to-man talk with the groom, hosting the engagement party, financing the increasingly lavish wedding, and wondering if Kay and Buckley will resolve their differences before arriving at the altar, Stanley barely has time to deal with his own considerable anxieties about his advancing age and how his “little girl” became a woman. Cast includes Spencer Tracy, Joan Bennett, Elizabeth Taylor and Don Taylor.

results.title: Dark passage
results.creator_credit: Delmer Daves, Jerry Wald, First National Pictures and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: Vincent Parry’s been framed! Wrongly convicted of murdering his wife, Parry (Bogart) busts out of San Quentin and heads for San Francisco, determined to clear himself. Once there, he takes shelter with Irene Jansen (Bacall), a young woman who believes his story and wants to help. Undergoing extensive plastic surgery, Parry drastically changes his appearance, but not his mission. Hidden by his new face, he evades blackmailer’s double-crossers and the cops in a final, desperate effort to find the real killer… before the killer finds him.

results.title: Marty
results.creator_credit: Delbert Mann, Harold Hecht, Hecht-Hill-Lancaster and United Artists Corporation
results.brief_description: In his Academy award winning performance for best actor (the film also won awards for Best Picture, Best Director and Best Writing, 1955), Ernset Borgnine went against character to portray sympathetic 34 year old single butcher, Marty. Marty is harangued by his mother (Esther Minciotti) to find a nice Italian girl and settle down like his younger siblings, yet paradoxically is surrounded by family who are in unhappy marriages. When Marty meets shy schoolteacher Clara (Betsy Blair) at a dance, Marty instantly finds a soulmate amongst his emotionally stifled and unhappy family and friends. To his surprise his blossoming relationship with Clara is challenged by his mother who feels threatened by the shy, yet educated and socially aware woman, and his friends who unkindly view her as a “dog”. Marty struggles to make up his mind whether to pursue happiness and flee his emotional isolation.

results.title: The Devil probably = Le Diablo problament [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Robert Bresson, Stephane Tchalgadjieff, M Chanderli Production and Sunchild GMF
results.brief_description: In hindsight, “The Devil probably” is one of the most prescient films to have arisen from the post-68 turmoil of French society. Bresson’s bleak but absorbing film examines the dissipated lives of young people who are aware they live in a world of ecological exploitation, and a world of consumerist greed, and whose response to that world is to drift into the apathy of unemployment, drugs, promiscuity and petty crime. The director, who also wrote the script, refuses to pathologise or romanticise his young characters and instead dignifies their stubborn resistance to conformity as a passive ethical opposition to a crumbling world. But he does not hide the ugliness or the cruelty of his characters. In this remarkable movie, Bresson explores the beginning of the western under-class which was to emerge with such alienated force at the end of the twentieth century. The film begins by posing a question: was a young man murdered or did he commit suicide? By the end of the film, this unanswerable question is left to haunt the viewer with its bitter suggestion that we are all in part responsible. In French with English subtitles. Cast includes Antoine Monnier, Tina Irassari and Laetita Carcano.

results.title: Mouchette
results.creator_credit: Robert Bresson, Anatole Dauman, Argos Films and Parc Film
results.brief_description: Based on the Georges Bernanos novel “Nouvelle histiore de Mouchette”, Robert Bresson’s unflinching tale of poverty and cruelty is an agonising and unsentimental film experience. Mouchette (Nadine Nortier) is a 14 year old peasant school girl. Her mother is dying and her father is a brutal alcoholic, leaving her to fend for herself and her baby brother amidst a harsh and indifferent community. When local poacher Arsene (Jean-Claude Guilbert) turns to Mouchette for an alibi over a possible murder, the young girl desperately responds to his neediness, unaware that she is being used yet again. Bresson strips scenes, performances and emotions down to their bare necessities, creating a unique style which at first might seem alienating but ultimately depicts the human experience with mystery, grace and poignancy. In French with English subtitles. Cast also includes Maria Cardinal, Paul Herbert, Jean Vimenet (Awards: Best film 1967 Venice Film festival)

results.title: Blade
results.creator_credit: Stephen Norrington, Peter Frankfurt, Robert Engelman, Wesley Snipes and Amen Ra Films
results.brief_description: This very sleek vampire thriller comes with a strange trio of superheroes. Whistler (Kris Kristofferson), a terminally ill motor mechanic whose lost his family to vampires; haematologist Karen (N’Bushe Wright) who carries the vampire blood but has the medical background to cure herself, and Blade (Wesley Snipes), part human and part vampire since he became infected while in his mother’s womb. Blade’s DNA holds the key to completing the Blood Tide - an event that will turn the rest of the population into vampires. Deacon Frost (Stephen Dorff), arch enemy of Blade and an upstart wannabe vampire (Frost became a vampire after being bitten and is not one of the pure breeds who has been a blood sucker since birth), is leading the charge to achieve Blood Tide, and he has the support of vampires to achieve it. Only 3 people stand in his way. From the opening sequence of the film that depicts a nightclub with a difference, this vibrant mixture of martial arts and rock video provides a very different take on the vampire genre. Cast also includes Donal Logue, Udo Kier and Traci Lords. Based on characters included in “Marvel comics”.

results.title: The Confessional = Le Confessionnal
results.creator_credit: Robert Robert Lepage, David Puttnam, Denise Robert, Philippe Carcassonne, Cinea, Cinemaginaire and Enigma Films
results.brief_description: Past, present and the world of cinema merge in this unique and visually innovate thriller. Quebec, 1952, and the church is abuzz as master director Alfred Hitchcock (played by Ron Burrage) is in town to film “I Confess”. An equally gripping story is going on in the background - the elements echoing that of the plot, as 16 year old church worker, Rachel (Suzanne Clement), is with child to an unknown father, only a young priest knows the truth. Quebec, 1989 and Pierre (Lothaire Bluteau) returns home to attend the funeral of his father. During his stay Pierre vows to solve the mystery of the parentage of his half brother, Marc (Patrick Goyette)- Rachel’s son, a discontented rent boy and father of a young child. Pierre’s mission is not an easy one, as the secrets of the past and heredity cloud the situation and find resonance in the future. Like the plot of Hitchcock’s film, only one man holds the key to past and present that was disclosed to him in the confines of the confessional. In French with English subtitles.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Robert Robert Lepage, David Puttnam, Denise Robert, Philippe Carcassonne, Cinea, Cinemaginaire and Enigma Films
results.description: Past, present and the world of cinema merge in this unique and visually innovate thriller. Quebec, 1952, and the church is abuzz as master director Alfred Hitchcock (played by Ron Burrage) is in town to film “I Confess”. An equally gripping story is going on in the background - the elements echoing that of the plot, as 16 year old church worker, Rachel (Suzanne Clement), is with child to an unknown father, only a young priest knows the truth. Quebec, 1989 and Pierre (Lothaire Bluteau) returns home to attend the funeral of his father. During his stay Pierre vows to solve the mystery of the parentage of his half brother, Marc (Patrick Goyette)- Rachel’s son, a discontented rent boy and father of a young child. Pierre’s mission is not an easy one, as the secrets of the past and heredity cloud the situation and find resonance in the future. Like the plot of Hitchcock’s film, only one man holds the key to past and present that was disclosed to him in the confines of the confessional. In French with English subtitles.
